π is the ratio between a circles perimeter and it\'s diameter. In Perfect Pi the goal is to draw a circle with that same ratio. Begrudgingly this is impossible. To begin with π has an infinite amount of decimals so however close you get it\'s always possible to get even closer. There are also technical limitations. The display consists of pixels which form a grid. So all figures drawn are represented by patterns of horizontal and vertical lines which when zoomed out can be made to look like round shapes. But if you\'re really good and witty you can still get a value close to π.

The computations are based on the isoperimetric inequality. It says that for all circles the inequality 4πA ≤ L² is true. This means that if you multiply a closed curve\'s area (A) with 4π the result will always be less or equal to the perimeter (L) squared.
By rewriting the isoperimetric inequality we end up with a relationship that can be used to compute the π-value for a circle (I).

When a user drags his finger on the display data is collected. This data is made up of points in an array. From every point a line is drawn to the subsequent point and when the user lifts his finger the computing starts.
Getting the length of the perimeter is easily done by adding the length of all the lines together. Calculating the area is a bit more tricky if you want a good result.

Pi is an irrational number, therefore it cannot be written as a fraction and it has an infinite decimal expansion. Two well-used approximations of Pi are 3,14 and 22/7.

About 250 years b.c Archimedes calculated an approximation of Pi by using an algorithm that consists of engraving a circle in between two polygons. By computing the circumference he found that the value of Pi was between 223/71 and 22/7. Because of this Pi is also called archimedes constant.

The identity e^(i*pi) + 1 = 0 is called Eulers identity and was discovered by Leonhard Euler in 1743. The identity is considered to be one the most beautiful equation in mathematics as it assembles the five most fundamentals numbers in mathematics: 0, 1, the unit of imaginary numbers ´i´, the base of natural logarithm ´e´ and ofcourse pi.

"Pi-day" is celebrated on March the 14th which was chosen to resemble the approximation 3,14. Many people like to start the celebration around 1:59 pm which combined with the date ressembles 3.14159, which is an even better approximation of Pi.

The worlds record for memorizing the value of Pi was won by the Chinese Chao Lu, whom in 2005 memorized and recited the value up to the 67 890 first decimal places.

The number Pi has a thousand year old story. Ever since the babylonians around 2000 years b.c estimated the value of pi to 25/8, mathematicians and civilizations have struggled and attempted to get a more precise value and today we have estimations of pi with several billions decimal places. In order to illustrate what an amazing and fascinating number pi is, we have collected some fun facts that we have encountered during the development of the app.
